isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 2000 4000 and 8000 MODELS BUILT OCTOBER 1, 1998 AND AFTER - ALLISON WT TRANSMISSION WITH WTEC III ELECTRONIC CONTROLS - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - NEUTRAL START SWITCH FUNCTION

svcproc.title: NEUTRAL START SWITCH FUNCTION
svcproc.para: The neutral start function is controlled by the WTEC III ECU using the neutral start relay located at the rear of the cab with 2000, 4000, 8000 and on the platform of the 3600, 3800 and 4000FBC. The relay then controls the start motor magnetic switch.

When the key is turned to the start position power is applied by the key switch (24) to circuits 13A and 13B, fuse F17, circuit 97P, connector (438)/(721), circuit 97P, connector (631), circuit 97P and pin 30 of the neutral start relay (615).

If the WTEC III ECU determines that the transmission is in neutral, 12V power from the ECU (632) will be applied from circuit 123 to the control coil pin 86 of the neutral start relay causing the relay to energize. The relay (615) is grounded through pin 85, circuits 143B and 143E, connector (418), circuit 143E, connector (13), circuit A343, connector (807), circuits A343 and 11-GA, connector (426), circuit 11-G, connector (665-B) and circuit 11-G to the negative battery terminal.

With the neutral start relay energized, power will flow from relay pin 87 through circuit 97AU, connector (631), circuit 97AU, connector (631), circuit 97AU, connector (720)/(438), circuit 97AU, connector (2), circuit 97AU, and connector (386). Power will also flow through the jumper, circuit 97A, connector (3), circuit 97A and pin 26 to the ECM (379). This will cause the ECM (379) to apply a ground to pin 46, circuit 97H, connector (3), and circuit 97H coming from the control coil of the crank inhibit relay (661). This will energize the relay which receives power from key switch on circuit 17. The jumper plug also supplies power to circuit 97L, and the contacts of crank inhibit relay (661). Thus with the crank inhibit relay (661) energized, power will flow through the normally open contacts of the energized crank inhibit relay (661) and through circuit 17F, connector (2), and circuit 17F to the start relay (387). Thus causing the engine to crank over.

To summarize the neutral start system: With the transmission in neutral and the key switch moved to the start position, voltage from the ECU energizes the neutral start relay, which closes, delivering voltage from the "S" terminal of the key switch through the neutral start relay and crank inhibit relay to energize the starter magnetic switch.
